citation.article-title: Taxonomy and description of Vibrio fluvialis sp. nov. (synonym group F vibrios, group EF6).

p.s: Description of Vibrio fluvialis sp. nov.
Vibrio fluvialis (flu.vi.a'lis, L. adj. of or belonging to a river)
(synonyms group F Furniss et al. (1977), group EF6 Huq et al. (1980)l.
Gram negative short rods; axis straight or curved; sides usually parallel; ends rounded; occurring singly, in pairs and occasionally in short chains of three to four organisms; may be pleomorphic.
Motile by means of a single polar sheathed flagellum in liquid media.
On solid media lateral, unsheathed flagella of shorter wave length may be produced.
Sodium chloride may be required for growth and the optimum concentration for growth is 1-3% (w/v).
Colonies on Heart Infusion Agar are opaque, shiny, smooth, round, domed, entire, may be mucoid and are 2-3 mm in diameter after 18 h at 30Â°C.
No pigments are produced.
Facultative anaerobe.
Metabolism of glucose is fermentative and gas may be produced.
Kovacs oxidase positive.
Reduce nitrate to nitrite.
Grow on simple mineral media on a variety of organic carbon sources.
The mol % G + C content of the DNA ranges from 49.3-50.6.
The species may be divided into biovars I and II.
The biochemical and physiological characteristics of the species, biovars, holotype and working type of biovar II are shown in Table 2.
Those characters particularly useful for the identification of the species and biovars are shown in Tables 4 and 5.
Biovar I strains are widely distributed throughout the aquatic environment particularly in brackish and estuarine waters but other sources have included shellfish and sewage.
They may also be isolated from the faeces of humans suffering with diarrhoea but their enteropathogenicity has not been firmly established.

Biovar II strains occur in the same aquatic habitats as biovar I but unlike them they are rarely, if ever, isolated from human faeces, They have, however, been isolated from faeces of cattle, pigs and rabbits.
The holotype is VL 5125 (strain 30) which has been deposited in the National Collection of Type Cultures as NCTC 11327.
We recommend VL 2386 (Strain 3) as a working type for biovar II and this has been acceded to the NCTC as NCTC 11328.
In addition we have deposited VL 2926 (strain 25), VL 5909 (strain 48) and VL 5975 (strain 49) under the numbers NCTC 11329, 11330 and 11331 respectively.
